Award.AwardTitle: The Rise of Insecure Work and Changes in Durable Inequality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how access to and experiences in skilled (and unskilled) and secure (and insecure) work has changed over time relative to workers' race and gender. It examines the period starting in the 1970s when minorities and women were gaining increasing access to skilled jobs, just as those positions were becoming increasingly insecure. The project poses five central questions. Do race, gender and skill shape exposure to and experiences of insecure work? Has employment insecurity become a distinguishing feature of racial and gender divisions? What do these broad economic changes mean in the lives of people? Do the narratives that men and women use to explain their own economic fortunes and struggles?and those of others?confirm or depart from the narratives that have been traditionally used to justify durable inequalities? How is the rise of insecure work affecting conceptions of masculinity and femininity, across different racial and class positions?

This study will answer these questions by studying employment insecurity, through the lens of racial and gender inequality, over the last 30 years. We utilize an innovative mixed-method approach with three components: (1) a cross-sectional panel based on Current Population Survey - Merged Outgoing Rotation Group (CPS-MORG) data from 1979 to 2012 which enables us to analyze trends over the past 30 years in exposure to insecure work; (2) an analysis of the CPS Contingent Worker Supplement (CPS-CWS) from 1995-2005 to document racial-gender variation in the experience of employment insecurity; and (3) 80 in-depth interviews to investigate the extent to which the rise of insecure work has disrupted or strengthened narratives of privilege and disadvantage in access to work. This three-pronged approach enables us to unpack the implications of the rise of insecure work for understanding racial and gender inequality, and determine the extent to which durable inequality has persisted or been transformed in the postindustrial era.

The proposed research advances social scientific understanding of employment insecurity and gauges the durability of racial and gender inequality. Our quantitative analysis builds and extends the existing literature on job insecurity by specifying its impact on different segments of the population. Our qualitative analysis goes a step further and focuses on how individuals conceptualize and make meaning of their experiences under insecure work conditions. Finally, having designed a multi-faceted plan for public engagement, we will use the findings and insights from our study to contribute to civic discussions of rising employment insecurity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Access to a job that paid a decent wage that enabled workers to support themselves and their families without fear of unexpected termination was something White men in the postwar (1940 -1970) economy, skilled and unskilled, took for granted. Just as minorities and women were gaining increasing access to these desirable jobs, in the 1970s, they were becoming more insecure. Postindustrial employment restructuring fundamentally reshaped the dynamics of the American labor market, producing lower wages, fewer employee benefits, diminished expectations of lifetime employment and fewer job ladders for upward mobility. While employment during the postwar period was organized around a primary labor market with stable and high-paying jobs, and a secondary labor market that supported it, postindustrial restructuring has erased that distinction. Employment conditions that used to apply only to the secondary and low-wage sector are now seen across industries, occupations, skill levels and wage levels, producing new forms of inequality at work. The overall picture that emerges from these trends is a proliferation of insecure jobs in terms of pay, stability and opportunities for advancement.

We utilize an innovative mixed-method approach with three components: (1) a cross-sectional panel based on Current Population Survey - Merged Outgoing Rotation Group (CPS-MORG) data from 1979 to 2015 which enables us to analyze trends over the past 35 years in exposure to insecure work; (2) an analysis of the CPS Contingent Worker Supplement (CPS-CWS) from 1995-2005 to document racial-gender variation in the experience of employment insecurity; and (3) 80 in-depth interviews (23 Black women, 21 Black men, 19 White women, and 17 White men); to explore how workers are using conceptions of race and gender—their own and others—to shape labor market expectations and make sense of increasing employment insecurity. This three-pronged approach enables us to unpack the implications of the rise of insecure work and gauges the durability of racial and gender inequality in the postindustrial era.

We reshape contemporary debates over economic insecurity by challenging the myth that insecure work is new. Instead, by adopting a historical perspective that is attentive to racial and gender differences, we show that the last 35 years are not about the rise of insecure work per se, but rather the redistribution of insecurity. It has become less confined to certain people in certain types of work since 1979. Working hard and getting a good education are no longer effective insurance policies against insecurity. And, the historical relationships between race, gender and economic security have shifted. Understanding economic insecurity through a historical and racial-gender lens helps us understand why White and Black Americans seem to have different perceptions of the present and optimism for the future. Our use of quantitative and qualitative data enables us to explore both the empirical reality and the lived experience of Black and White Americans navigating insecure times.

A historical, comparative perspective that is attentive to race-gender and nuanced in its measurement of insecurity yields a more accurate picture of then and now. Our study can help the public and experts alike to understand why men and women, black and white, have both shared and divergent experiences of economic insecurity. While insecurity was always a lived reality for some Americans, its experience was reserved for a notable few, sustaining the belief that if you did the right things, e.g. obtained a higher education or worked in a particular occupational sector, you could avoid it. Finally, it provides a path for new research that is attentive to categorical inequality as we seek to understand new forms of inequality and the future of work.
